4:39 There's a mistake here, the fact that you're decelerating has nothing to do with the fact that you're under a sense of gravity again; otherwise, when the engines stop in the climb, and you decelerate, that would work too.

In reality, what happens is that you are no longer subjected only to gravity, there is the atmosphere which prevents you from undergoing only gravity, and thus it is not you who slows down, since all the reference frames are equal, but the atmosphere which prevents you from experiencing gravity alone. You are therefore no longer in an inertial reference frame.

The atmosphere acts as a resistance, and the weight that you feel has no relation with you, but only between the density of the atmosphere and the gravity. A bit like when you fall in the water, technically speaking the gravity is the same, but the water prevents you from feeling it fully and acts as a brake.



Some may accuse me of playing with words, but think again, this is an extremely fundamental and problematic error.

Rocket propulsion will not work within a vacuum environment, as the very moment that any thrust exits the exhaust port, this thrust is immediately overwhelmed by the surrounding overwhelming vacuum.
The old-adage "For every reaction there is an equal and opposite reaction!" sounds nice but does not mean rocket propulsion works in space.
In order for the thrust from a rocket to propel a rocket into motion, this rocket-thrust would need to first overwhelm the surrounding overwhelming vacuum prior to initiating any motion.
A given atmospheric back-pressure is essential for rocket thrust. This same issue applies to any pressurized nitrogen gas-thrusters; the very same as it applies to propellers and jet-propulsion.
No man nor anything manmade has ever been through the Van-Allen radiation belt, which functions very much like an impenetrable force-field.

Firstly, both of these systems rely on the statistical likelihood of surviving a controlled crash. The BO capsule has no control over it's landing site and crashes onto a random spot in the desert, where the passengers will have to wait for recovery, while hoping that the vehicle doesn't go boom. Due to weight versus total rocket impulse issues, the VG rocket glider doesn't get past the 100 km line, has flimsy main gears and wheels, and has a nose skid instead of wheels. In the aviation world, it's return to the ground is known as an emergency landing. Neither system appears to be commercially viable, as both will suffer damage and require inspection and repair after every flight. The funniest part ... VG needs four pilots to get six passengers not quite into space.

Nice video - Never gave thought to the "falling upward weightlessness" where at engine shutdown the craft is now accelerating back toward the ground, but has an upward, but decreasing velocity (you are weightless). At apogee velocity is zero then starts increasing downward, all the while acceleration is pretty much constant (you are still weightless) until atmospheric drag starts to reduce that acceleration. The difference of which determines your apparent "weight" inside the craft.  For example if you are decelerating at 8 m/sec^2 because of air resistance  in a 9.8 m/sec^2 gravity field you would experience what you would feel in a gravity field of about 1.8 m/sec^2 something close to moon gravity. Of course when the craft is no longer accelerating (decelerating) you feel normal earth gravity, e.g. level flight, constant velocity with parachute deployed or of course after landing. Having written all this, I never gave any thought to being weightless in the first phase after engine shutdown, despite being an engineer and all that. The accelerating downward part is what most of us are familiar with having jumped off a high diving board... Never was bold enough to do be launched by a trebuchet.

I don't approve of the "hydrogen rocket fuel = clean" fallacy going around. 99% of all hydrogen produced is just steam reformed methane, which releases exactly the same amount of CO2 as just burning the methane would. In reality methane is a cleaner rocket fuel than hydrogen, because you don't waste energy on the conversion and just run on all the available power. Hydrogen fuel seems to be a giant green-washing scheme for fossil gas. Of course you could use electrolysis, but no one does that at any scale, since the process is very wasteful (about 75% energy lost).

What's the turnaround time?

BO needs to check and pack the parachutes and change the landing charges on the capsule then move it back to the booster for stacking. The booster then needs refuelling.

VG needs to tow the ship into the hangar, swap the rubber engines, mount it under the carrier, load oxidiser and RCS gas, plus refuel the carrier aircraft. In addition to the 2 hour trip.

Some things (e.g. parachutes, solid fuel engine) can be held in store and reprocessed over time, but the number of flights per week per vehicle could be critical - especially in the early days when prices are high.

04:05 - Oh no, that's just wrong. You and the spacecraft are accelerating after engine shut off, it's what the force of gravity is causing! Just the spacecraft and all its contents, including you, are now accelerating uniformly so that there's no local experience of resistance to that acceleration.

Weight, after all, isn't only due to gravity, you also need something resisting the acceleration gravity wants to cause, i.e. the ground.

Likewise on the way down you start to feel weight again when the spacecraft experiences sufficient aerodynamic drag for it to no longer be accelerating only under gravity. Your body inside is shielded from that drag so would otherwise continue accelerating under only gravity, but instead the interior of the spaceship is now preventing your body from doing so, and thus you start feeling weight again.

What would be far better is if we invested in Molten Salt Thorium thermal reactor-based rapidly reusable 1st stages, then used those to launch Starships into orbit.

Molten salt thorium thermal reactors can allow for a substantially higher ISP in converting liquid hydrogen to nearly plasma, and because of the molten nature of the fuel, they can easily be refilled and have the extremely small amount of nuclear waste generated each time be pulled out of the reactor so that it can always operate at high efficiency.

Once we have this system in place, we could make space flight (as in, actual orbital flights) substantially cheaper so that more people can afford to go up.

These suborbital flights might actually harm the space flight industry because it makes space seem more like a temporary theme park that uses ridiculous amounts of fuel (remember, suborbital flights have a substantially lower ratio of time in space to fuel used than orbital flights, by a mind-bogglingly large factor).

Unity needs it's engine changed out, and New Shepherd needs to be retrieved from the desert, it's parachutes re-folded and re-packed, and the whole system re-stacked. This is never going to be a quick turn-around like you get with an airplane.

In that sense, I don't really get why New Shepherd doesn't land propulsively as a single unit, only separating the capsule as an abort when needed in any stage of the flight. After hearing that a thousand times, here and there, there is actually an explanation to be made...
The word "parachute" is from French language. It was created in 1785 by Louis-Sébastien Lenormand, the first ever man to use such a device and jump with it (with two small ones, actually, one in each hand). The purpose of his invention was to save persons from fires in collective housings (as they were getting more an more popular in cities), and allow them to escape in case of staircases being unusable. He performed one of his tests before the very eyes of Joseph Montgolfier, who happened to be the co-inventor of the "montgolfiere" (hot-air ballon) with his brother Jacques-Etienne.
Lenormand used two words combined together to simply create "parachute" : "para" (Latin word) meaning "against" or "to protect from" + "chute" (French word) meaning "fall" or "free fall".
So... using only "chute" (the later half of the very "parachute" word) results in meaning the exact opposite of the true meaning of the full extense. And I don't see any point, or increase in precision, or whatever, in doing so.
Is that so exhausting to say "parachute", and be accurate, meaningful...?
It's not targeted towards anyone specifically, but if we're to deal with science-related topics, some accuracy is more than welcome.
And transmitting the exact opposite of what you were meant to explain is... not being accurate. At all.

4:09. ⚠️⚠️‼️⚠️⚠️ Yes you absolutely are accelerating. You have a negative acceleration as you climb to apogee. At apogee for an infinitesimal small period of time you have 0 acceleration in relationship to the ground. You then start a positive acceleration back to the ground. You feel weightless because you, your insides, and the space plane are all accelerating / decelerating at exactly the same rate.

Acceleration is only delta V. Fall out of a plane. You feel weightless even though you are accelerating to terminal velocity.

The explanation misses one important point. What causes weightlessness? When accelerating up the crew experiences more than 1 g because inertial force is acting in the same direction as gravitational force but after engine shutdown they should be experiencing normal 1 g gravity not weightlessness. However centrifugal force due to parabolic trajectory cancels gravity. The flight is thus not space weightlessness but a big roller coaster ride, therefore the horizontal speed is essential to produce sense of weightlessness. However since orbital weightlessness is also due to cetrifugal force it is not so much different.

Karman Line definition - this is named after Theodore von Karman who was trying to define an altitude at which the atmosphere can no longer support aerodynamic flight. This height is a matter of intense debate and Karman himself estimated it at 51.9 miles. Thus the US definition of 50 miles is pretty well the best approximation. The French dominated FAI use of 100 km (62 miles) is accepted by many as merely another attempt to metricate everything.

I would have liked if you touched more on how the atmosphere doesn't actually stop and how 80km is also in space given the reasoning behind 100km. An astoundingly small number of people realize that the atmosphere extends so far that it's actually measurable even at the moon. Barely measurable, but measurable.

The atmosphere is extremely volatile at the edges and is affected by things as small as solar wind. As such, the barrier of space is from the point at which you would have to travel faster than orbital velocity to maintain aeronautical flight.

It's also important to note that the mesopause is 85km-100km, and the upper bound is where the karman line is. Technically 80km is still in the mesosphere.

The New Shepard is very similar to the original Mercury/Redstone rocket that Alan Shepard rode up on in his sub orbital flight that made him the first American in space. The Virgin Galactic SpaceShip Two is very similar to the even earlier X-15 flights where the X-15 was carried up to a high altitude by a B-52 and then released and the X-15 then fired its engine and ascended to a high altitude to then glide back down to an airplane style landing on a runway. All Bezos and Branson have done is duplicate what the early pioneers of space flight did 60 years ago. A nice accomplishment in that they both will bring space flights to the masses, well, very rich masses, but, as far as technology is concerned, we've seen all this 60 years ago. Ego’s aside, and how this was done sixty years ago… It IS thrilling to see Branson climb another rung of the orbital ladder. After the Challenger shuttle crash my mentor Bill Mouton and I explored space-launches, rethought limitations, and saw Chuck Yeager's X-1A space-plane as touchstone for a safer, cheaper, and saner way.
For two years we applied ourselves to pitching and educating the Shuttle Launcher concept, but NASA remained in shock, catatonic, and our ideas lay fallow for a generation.
Memes evolve. Today we see Virgin Galactic as a sleek iPad-style design in modern aerodynamics & composites applied to Von Braun inspiration and Allen's Vulcan Stratolaunch the direct industrial-scale successor to Mouton's "Deuce Goose". These prove our design goals; the catamaran safely pops-up and away before ignition, dramatically lower fuel-loads save money + environment impacts… we even foresaw landing spacecraft at municipal airports, as Heinlein intended.

In total contrast, everything about Virgin's design and construction feels dangerously flimsy, including the carrier aircraft which reportedly has developed structural fatigue problems of its own. I'm also not a fan of an old school, human operated spaceplane design (not even fly-by-wire!!!!). Remember, this is supposed to be a high-cadence commercial operation for tourists, not a once-in-several-years space mission. Human fatigue and carelessness WILL creep in. And then people will die. Or metal fatigue will set in. And then people will die. Or the carrier aircraft will split in two mid-flight. And then people will die.

Virgin has already killed FOUR people, and they're rushing this flight with Branson, no matter what they say publicly. We are absolutely witnessing Go Fever. It's the opposite of Blue Ball's "ferociously slow" approach, and it will get people killed. You couldn't pay me to ride that SpacePlane O' Death.

Something you could spin to get at least partial "gravity" to counteract the fact that free fall is bad for humans. Something you could actually live on for your entire life.
